Report and Recommendation of the President  
to the Board of Directors
 
 
Project Number: 49222-001 
November 2016 
 
 
 
 
Proposed Loan 
HSBC Bank USA, National Association 
Tangguh Liquefied Natural Gas Expansion Project 
 
(Indonesia)
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This is an abbreviated version of the document approved by ADB's Board of Directors that 
excludes  information  that  is  subject  to  exceptions  to  disclosure  set  forth  in  ADB's  Public 
Communications Policy 2011.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 5 October 2016) 
Currency unit  –  rupiah (Rp) 
Rp1.00  =  $0.0001     
$1.00  =  Rp13,038     
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  BPCNAI  –  BP Corporation North America Inc. 
  EPC  –  engineering, procurement, and construction 
  ESIA  –  environmental and social impact assessment 
  LNG  –  liquefied natural gas 
  PLN  –  Perusahaan Listrik Negara (national power utility) 
  POD  –  plan of development 
  PSC  –  production sharing contract 
  RIPP  –  resettlement and indigenous peoples plan 
  S&P  –  Standard & Poor’s 
  TBS  –  trustee borrowing scheme 
 
WEIGHTS AND MEASURES 
 
  Bcm  –  billion cubic meter 
  GW  –  gigawatt 
  mmtpa  –  million metric tons per annum 
  tcf  –  trillion cubic feet 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.

Vice-President  D. Gupta, Private Sector and Cofinancing Operations 
Director General  M. Barrow, Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) 
Director  C. Thieme, Officer-in-Charge, Infrastructure Finance Division 2, PSOD 
   
Team leader  X. Pu, Principal Investment Specialist, PSOD

  M. Tonizzo, Investment Specialist, PSOD

designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

CONTENTS 
 
Page

II.  THE PROJECT  1 
A.  Project Identification and Description  1 
B.  Development Impacts, Outcome, and Output  4 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  4 
D.  Project Cost and Financing Plan  5 
E.  Implementation Arrangements  5 
F.  Projected Financial and Economic Performance  5 
III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE  5 
A.  The Assistance  5 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance  6 
C.  Risks  6

A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions  7

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
of up to $400,000,000 to HSBC Bank USA, National Association for the Tangguh Liquefied 
Natural Gas Expansion Project in Indonesia.1 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
1.  Project Identification 
2.  The  Tangguh  natural  gas  liquefaction  facility  has  been  converting  natural  gas  into 
liquefied natural gas (LNG) since 2009 in West Papua Province, Indonesia’s least-developed 
region.  Together  with  the  Japan  Bank  for  International  Cooperation  and  international 
commercial banks, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) funded the greenfield development of 
the plant’s first two LNG production units, called trains, in 2006. The ADB loan for trains 1 and 2 
was fully prepaid in 2014.2  
 
3.  LNG production from trains 1 and 2 has exceeded expectations, and the sponsors now 
want to expand the facility by adding a third train. State-owned Perusahaan Listrik Negara (PLN, 
the  national  power  utility)  has  committed  to  buy  75%  of  train  3’s  production  to  generate 
electricity for the domestic market. The remaining 25% of the new unit’s LNG output has been 
committed to Kansai Electric of Japan. 
 
4.  Supporting cleaner power generation using indigenous fuel. Indonesia’s economy 
is Southeast Asia’s largest. Gross domestic product was an estimated $888.5 billion in 2014, 
and economic growth since the 1997 Asian financial crisis has averaged about 5% a year. The 
country has transitioned from a resource- and export-based economy to a manufacturing one, 
but the energy sector has not kept pace with either the overall growth or change.3 Investment in 
exploration for and the production, transport, conversion, and distribution of energy has been 
inadequate  and  often  carried  out  inefficiently.4 The  power  subsector  has fallen  particularly 
behind.  The  Ministry  of  Energy  and  Mineral  Resources  estimates  that  rising  demand  for 
electricity, which is forecasted to increase by 8.5% per annum under the current economic 
growth projections, will create a power shortage of about 35 gigawatts (GW) before 2020. 
 
5.  The  Government  of  Indonesia  is  facilitating  PLN’s  procurement5 of  new  generation 
capacity through an expansion program in which 13 of 35 GW are expected to be gas-fired 
                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  ADB. 2005. Reports and Recommendations of the President to the Board of Directors Tangguh Liquefied Natural 
Gas Project. Manila 
3  In 2013, Indonesia’s national office of statistics estimated that gross domestic product derived from the following 
sectors: manufacturing (24%); agriculture (14%); trade, hotel, and hospitality (14%); mining and quarrying (11%); 
construction (10%); government and private services (11%); finance, real estate, and business services (8%); 
transport and communication (7%); and electricity, gas, and water supply (1%). 
4  ADB. 2015. Summary of Indonesia’s Energy Sector Assessment. ADB Papers on Indonesia, No. 9. Manila. 
5  A 2009 electricity law formally ended PLN’s monopoly on the power sector. However, the utility is still the major 
provider of electricity infrastructure in the country and owns roughly 85% of the total generation capacity. To deal 
with the projected power shortage, the government introduced a series of programs to fast-track power generation 
expansion. The latest, launched in 2015, targets the development of 35 GW of new power generation capacity, 
36% of which is expected to be gas-fired.

2   
power plants.6 At present, natural gas accounts for about 25% of PLN fuel mix, but the utility has 
been  struggling  to  ensure  steady  and  reliable  supply  while  competing  with  growing 
manufacturing and petrochemical businesses that have driven the growth of gas’ domestic 
demand.7 . The LNG from Tangguh will ensure to PLN the much needed relief from intermittent 
gas supply and support the expansion of PLN’s growing gas-fired generation capacity. 
 
6.  Supporting sustainable growth. The Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources sees a 
greater role for natural gas as important to its goal of reducing the use of oil and coal in the 
country, particularly for power generation. The use of gas-fired generation can improve the 
environmental sustainability of the current energy mix by displacing diesel and coal as fuels for 
peak electricity generation. Gas engines and turbines can ramp up more quickly than coal and 
diesel-fired units and thus are better suited to responding rapidly to load fluctuations. This in 
turn can enable greater use of renewable energy sources such as wind and solar that can 
provide power only intermittently, as well as eliminate the need to invest in the large and 
expensive battery storage capacity these renewable systems might otherwise require.8 ADB 
calculates that using the gas from the new train 3 to generate power rather than coal could 
result in emission savings of up to 9.15 million tons of carbon dioxide equivalent per year. 
 
7.  The project is also of important to Indonesia’s future economic growth. The country was 
one of the world’s largest LNG exporters in the early 1990s, accounting for almost 25% of global 
LNG exports.9 Competition from new entrants in the LNG export markets had reduced this share 
to only about 6.6% by 2015.10 Meanwhile, the country’s gas reserves have been declining, and 
new fields are increasingly smaller, more remote, and located in deeper waters. This makes 
them more costly to exploit. The development of train 3 at the Tangguh plant will help the 
country expand use of an existing gas reserve at a cost that is competitive with other large LNG 
developments. This is because of the economies of scale that will be achieved by building on 
the existing LNG facilities. The 25% of production committed to the export market will help the 
government maintain access to hard currency. 
 
8.  Supporting inclusive growth in eastern Indonesia. The project will enable ADB to 
continue making a positive impact on the inclusive growth in eastern Indonesia it achieved 
under its earlier project to develop the facility’s first and second trains.11 That project was rated 
excellent for private sector development by both ADB’s extended annual review report12 and the 
subsequent validation report by ADB’s Independent Evaluation Department. Inclusive growth 
was achieved by creating thousands of jobs and helping to improve livelihoods in one of the 
poorest regions of Indonesia. The initial Tangguh LNG operation was the first upstream oil and 
                                                
6  The energy division of the Southeast Asia Department of ADB is proposing to support the government with a $500 
million sector loan to help improve access to electricity services in eastern Indonesia. The loan would help PLN 
develop a cluster of new small to medium-sized gas-fired power stations. The new power stations will have lower 
generation costs and emit less pollutants and carbon dioxide than similar diesel-fired units. The concept paper for 
this project was cleared in March 2016. 
7  Indonesia’s LNG consumption grew from 35.7 billion cubic meters (bcm) in 2004 to 38.4 bcm in 2014, peaking at 
43.4 bcm in 2010. The year-on-year growth in 2014 was 5.1%, compared with 2% growth in the Asia and Pacific 
region and 0.4% globally. Source: BP. 2015. BP Statistical Review of World Energy 2015. 
8  For example, an off-the-shelf Wartsila gas engine has a ramp-up rate of 100 MW per minute, which means that the 
engine goes from zero to 50 MW of power generation capacity in just 30 seconds. The proposed ADB loan 
(footnote 6) will include some pilot gas-solar hybrid units in loan projects being discussed with PLN. 
9 International Gas Union. World LNG Report – 2016 Edition. 
10 International Gas Union (2016). 
11 ADB. 2014. Validation Report: Tangguh Liquefied Natural Gas Project. Manila 
12 ADB. 2012. Extended Annual Review Report: Tangguh Liquefied Natural Gas Project in Indonesia. Manila

3 
gas project in Indonesia developed through public consultations with local communities and 
governments that were led by ADB environmental and social safeguards teams. 
 
2.  Project Design 
9.  Trains 1 and 2 of the Tangguh plant were designed to produce 3.8 million metric tons 
per annum (mmtpa) of LNG each. The output has been sold to buyers in the People’s Republic 
of China, Japan, the Republic of Korea, and the United States through long-term agreements. 
Train 3 is expected to have the same capacity as each of the first two and thus expand the 
facility’s existing LNG production by 50%.  The project will add the third 3.8 mmtpa LNG train as 
well as the associated offshore and onshore facilities and other supporting infrastructure. The 
new train is expected to start operations in 2020. 
 
10.  The onshore train 3 facility will be constructed adjacent to trains 1 and 2, using smart 
standardization—i.e.,  using  the  same  specifications  as  those  for  the  first  two  trains  with 
alterations based on the lessons learned over the plant’s 7 years of operations and the latest 
best practices in the industry. Two additional offshore unmanned platforms are going to be 
developed for this purpose.13 The fields supplying the Tangguh facilities are within the Berau, 
Muturi, and Wiriagar concession areas covered by three production sharing contracts (PSCs) 
entered  into  between  several  international  oil  and  gas  companies  and  the  government, 
represented by a special task force for upstream oil and gas business activities established by 
presidential decree.14  
 
11.  As was the case in all other LNG projects in Indonesia, including the existing Tangguh 
plant, the project will be financed through a trustee borrowing scheme (TBS). The TBS is a 
financing scheme developed in 1986 to facilitate financing for the Bontang LNG project within 
the government’s regulatory framework that limits the ownership of upstream oil and gas assets 
to the government. Since then, all LNG projects in the country have been financed under the 
TBS. Under the TBS, financiers lend funds to an offshore trustee acting as borrower and paying 
agent. The funds are in turn made available to the project. All LNG revenues are sent directly to 
the offshore trustee. The trustee makes the loan interest payments and principal repayments to 
lenders out of a percentage of LNG revenues that is called the source of debt service. These 
payments are made before (with respect to source of debt service only) other costs or taxes are 
deducted. 
 
3.  Project Sponsors 
12.  Based on the three Tangguh PSCs, the working interests in the Tangguh LNG project 
are shared between the government (through the special task force for upstream oil and gas 
business activities) and 10 experienced international oil and gas contractors. The sponsors 
include  BP  and  CNOOC,  Japan  Oil,  Gas,  and  Metals  National  Corporation  (JOGMEC), 
Mitsubishi  Corporation,  INPEX  Corporation,  JX  Nippon,  Mitsui,  Sojitz  Corporation,  and 
Sumitomo Corporation. BP Berau, a subsidiary of BP, operates the project on behalf of the 
sponsors. 
 
 
                                                
13 Trains 1 and 2 are fed by two offshore unmanned platforms that extract gas from the Vorwata field, which is the 
only one currently developed in the concession area. 
14 Details of Implementation Arrangements (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

4   
13.  Guarantee.  BP  Corporation  North  America  Inc.  (BPCNAI)  will  fully  guarantee  the 
proposed ADB loan. The unconditional and irrevocable guarantee is expected to cover the 
project’s entire payment obligation under the ADB loan. BPCNAI is a wholly owned subsidiary of 
BP and its largest subsidiary worldwide. In 2015, it recorded total sales of $223 billion. BPCNAI 
is currently rated A3 with a positive outlook by  Moody's and A– with a stable outlook by 
Standard & Poor's (S&P). 
 
B.  Development Impacts, Outcome, and Output 
14.  Impacts. The Tangguh LNG expansion will provide much-needed natural gas to help 
meet  rapidly  growing  domestic  demand,  particularly  in  the  power  sector.  In  line  with  the 
government’s policy, the project will support development of a more sustainable fuel mix to 
reduce carbon emissions by using natural gas to displace coal or diesel in powering electricity 
generation (para. 5). This will help improve the quality of life in Indonesia and be a key driver of 
greater economic activity. The project will accelerate economic development in the province of 
West Papua, providing additional local employment opportunities and scope for human resource 
development in one of the country’s poorest regions. 
 
15.  Outcome.  The  outcome  will  be  increased  gas  production  for  domestic  use.  The 
Tangguh facility’s production capacity is expected to expand from 7.6 mmtpa to 11.4 mmtpa per 
annum with the addition of train 3, 75% of which is committed to help meet domestic demand for 
electricity.  
 
16.   Output. The output will be the completion of train 3 and the related infrastructure. This 
will  include  the  completion  and  start  of  operations  of  two  additional  offshore  unmanned 
platforms; 29 kilometers of undersea gas pipeline; one additional LNG jetty; the additional 3.8 
mmtpa LNG production train; one additional utility for power generation; and additional water 
treatment,  wastewater  treatment,  and  appropriate  expansion  of  solid  waste  management 
facilities. 
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
17.  Consistency with ADB Strategy and country strategy. The project aligns with ADB’s 
Midterm  Review  of  Strategy  2020  by  promoting  environmentally  sustainable  growth.  15 
Expanding the LNG infrastructure and domestic gas supply in Indonesia has the potential to 
offset greenhouse gas emissions generated by coal-fired or diesel-fired power plants. The 
project is also consistent with ADB’s interim country partnership strategy for Indonesia for 
2015,16 because it seeks to improve Indonesia’s energy security, diversify its domestic fuel mix 
diversification,  and  support  economic  growth  in  the  less-developed  eastern  region  of  the 
country.  
 
18.  Consistency  with  sector  strategy  and  relevant  ADB  operations.  In  line  with 
Indonesia’s  National  Energy  Policy17 and  ADB’s  Energy  Policy,18 ADB  has  focused  on 
promoting power-generation alternatives that are more sustainable than coal- and diesel-fired 
generation. While coal and diesel are still the dominant fuels in Indonesia’s energy mix, ADB is 
committed through its public and private sector operations to support the development of the 
                                                
15 ADB. 2014. Midterm Review of Strategy 2020: Meeting the Challenges of a Transforming Asia and Pacific. Manila. 
16 ADB. 2015. Indonesia Partnership Strategy. Manila. https://www.adb.org/countries/indonesia/strategy  
17 Government of Indonesia. 2014. National Energy Policy. Jakarta. 
18 ADB. 2009. Energy Policy. Manila.

5 
gas sector, and in turn to help provide the country with stable base-load electricity generated by 
a fuel that emits less carbon emissions than coal and diesel. Energy projects that utilize natural 
gas and efficient combined cycle technology can contribute to economic development in a more 
sustainable manner than coal- or diesel-fired projects. 
 
D.  Project Cost and Financing Plan 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  Table 2 summarizes the implementation arrangements.14 
 
Table 1: Summary of Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Regulatory framework  Indonesia’s Oil and Gas Law 22/2001 provides the framework for the oil and gas 
industry in the country. The law distinguishes between upstream and downstream 
activities. Upstream activities are to be conducted under cooperation contracts with the 
government’s special working unit. This is currently the special task force for upstream 
oil and gas business activities, based on presidential regulation number 9 of 2013.  
Management and  BP Berau is the operator of the Tangguh LNG facility. BP Berau is a wholly owned 
operations  subsidiary of BP. The operator has remained unchanged since the start of the plant’s 
operations in 2009. BP Berau will operate train 3 after the plant’s expansion in a fully 
integrated manner with the two existing trains. 
Implementation period  [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
Construction  [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
arrangements 
Revenue structure  The LNG output of train 3 has been fully committed through two sales and purchase 
agreements with PLN and Kansai Electric Power. PLN has revenue equal to Rp292.72 
trillion and ranks 477 on the Fortune Global 500 list. PLN has ratings of Baa3 with 
Moody’s, BBB– with Fitch, and BB with Standard & Poor’s. Kansai is one of the 10 
major electric utility companies in Japan. Kansai is listed with a market capitalization of 
Y1.3 trillion as of 11 January 2016 and is rated A3 by Moody’s. 
Performance monitoring  Key performance indicators, including output and outcome indicators, will be reported 
by BP Berau on behalf of the production sharing contractors. 
LNG = liquefied natural gas, PLN = Perusahaan Listrik Negara (national power utility). Source: Asian Development 
Bank. 
 
F.  Projected Financial and Economic Performance 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
A.  The Assistance 
20.  ADB will provide a direct loan of $400 million to the trustee borrower, HSBC Bank USA, 
National Association. The loan will be guaranteed by BPCNAI, which is currently rated A3 by 
Moody’s and A– by S&P.

6   
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
21.  ADB’s role in the project will be similar to the one it played in the financing for the initial 
two trains of the Tangguh LNG facility. It will mitigate the risks for all the stakeholders of 
substandard implementation of environmental and social safeguards. ADB’s additionality in the 
original  Tangguh  LNG  greenfield  development  project  was  rated  excellent:  ADB’s  work 
promoted sustainable LNG development and inclusive growth (footnote 12). The value added by 
ADB  in  the  greenfield  development  was  confirmed  in  ADB’s  Independent  Evaluation 
Department’s validation report and in these ways has been repeatedly cited publicly by the 
government and BP. ADB due diligence for the proposed project showed that ADB can help 
improve some of the environmental and social safeguards during the operation so that they 
meet international standards that go beyond those set by Indonesia’s law. The sponsors have 
recognized the additional positive value of ADB’s participation in the financing and execution of 
the original Tangguh development and have asked that it continue this support through the 
plant’s expansion. This will ensure that the safeguard achievements of the initial operation will 
be sustained.  
 
C.  Risks 
25.   Sponsor risk. The sponsor group includes a combination of state-owned enterprises 
and large conglomerates with substantial experience in natural gas, petrochemical and derived 
products trading, manufacturing and distribution.  
 
26.  Project  completion  risk.  As  an  expansion  of  an  existing  brownfield  project,  the 
Tangguh  LNG  expansion  should  experience  reduced  construction  and  operational  risks. 
Lessons learned from trains 1 and 2 are well-understood and will be applied in the design and 
construction of train 3, with BP Berau serving as project manager for the expansion.  
 
27.  Operation and management risk. BP Berau, the operator of Tangguh, will manage 
train 3 as part of an integrated LNG production complex. In addition to its parent’s global 
experience on LNG projects, BP Berau has a solid track record of successful operations at 
Tangguh  and  is  well-positioned  to  manage  the  expanded  LNG  facility,  particularly  from  a 
technical and staffing perspective. 
 
28.  Offtake and pricing risks. The project has contracted long-term take-or-pay sales and 
purchase agreements with PLN and Kansai Electric Power covering 100% of the total estimated 
train 3 production, effectively mitigating offtake risk.  
 
29.  Gas reserve risk. [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
30.  Foreign exchange risk. Revenue from LNG proceeds will be paid entirely in US dollar. 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
31.  Guarantor risk. The guarantor risk is acceptable. BPCNAI guarantees the project’s debt 
service to ADB.  
 
32.  Environmental  and  social  risks.  Environmental  and  social  impacts and  mitigation 
measures are comprehensively addressed in an environmental and social impact assessment 
(ESIA)  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  requirements.  Greater  use  of  LNG  is  recognized  as  an 
important part of the change in the energy mix required to transition to a low-carbon economy.

7 
Based  on  energy  produced  or  consumed,  LNG  use  can  result  in  lower  emissions  of  the 
greenhouse gases implicated in global warming than the use of coal or diesel.  
 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
33.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project is classified 
category A for environment and indigenous people and category B for involuntary resettlement. 
The potential environmental and social impacts of the project have been identified and effective 
measures  to  avoid,  minimize,  mitigate,  and  compensate  for  the  adverse  impacts  are 
incorporated in the safeguard reports and plans. The institutional capacity and commitment of 
the sponsors to manage the project’s social and environmental impacts are deemed adequate. 
 
34.  Environment. Because the project involves the expansion of the existing LNG facility 
and infrastructure and operations similar to those of the original two trains, most of the required 
environmental safeguards measures and the institutional capacity are already in place, as is a 
commitment to meet these standards. In accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement, 
an audit of the existing facilities was carried out, and the project sponsors have agreed to take 
the limited number of corrective actions recommended in audit report.19 The government has 
approved the project on the basis of an environmental and social impact assessment (analisis 
mengenai dampak lingkungan [AMDAL]) prepared by BP Berau in 2014 that meets Indonesia’s 
own requirements. ADB has requested that supplements be added to the assessment to bring it 
into line with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement requirements. 20 The project is located in an 
area of biodiversity significance and classified by ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement as critical 
habitat. A critical habitat assessment has demonstrated that the project is able to operate in 
compliance with the critical habitat requirements of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. 
 
35.  The operations of train 3 will generate additional emissions which will meet be monitored 
to ensure they meet local requirements and international discharge standards. Before and 
during construction, the EPC contractor will be required to develop and implement detailed 
construction  environmental  and  safety  management  plans  that  are  consistent  with  BP’s 
stringent requirements and ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. 
 
36.  Social  safeguards.  The  social  safeguards  compliance  audit  undertaken  on  the 
construction and operation of trains 1 and 2 under the previous ADB project concludes that prior 
involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples were managed in compliance with the ADB 
safeguard policies applicable at that time and ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement.21 Closure of 
one outstanding issue on land titling in the village of Onar Baru was completed at the end of 
2016.  
 
37.  The project is classified category B for involuntary resettlement and category A for 
indigenous peoples. No additional land is required, and no physical displacement is expected. A 
bulk off-loading facility will affect the subsistence of 17 foot-fisherfolks in Tanah Merah village. 
                                                
19 Compliance Audit Report: http://www.adb.org/projects/documents/ino-tangguh-lng-expansion-may-2016-ecar 
20 Environmental  and  Social  Impact  Assessment  including  AMDAL  and  supplementary  appendixes: 
http://www.adb.org/projects/documents/ino-tangguh-lng-expansion-may-2016-esia  
21 The outcome was also previously confirmed by ADB;s extended annual review report in 2012 (footnote 12).

8   
Temporary disturbance to their fishing activities is expected during the construction of one of the 
two offshore platforms. People affected by economic displacement due to the project will be 
provided  with  livelihood  development  programs  under  the  ADB  project’s  resettlement  and 
indigenous  peoples  plan  (RIPP).  The  RIPP  incorporates  the  Tangguh  Social  Management 
(TSM)  which  embodies  the  Project’s  long  term  commitments  and  the  5-yearly  Tangguh 
Sustainable Development Program (TSDP 2016-2020) formulated by the operator, BP Berau. 
Indigenous peoples residing in the Tangguh social influence area along the coast of Bintuni Bay 
are expected to be adversely affected by project activities and targeted as beneficiaries under 
the RIPP. The RIPP will be implemented by capable, experienced staff from the project’s 
communications and external affairs team. The Tangguh project has allocated sufficient budget 
to carry out the programs and activities agreed with the government and the local community. 
 
38.  The RIPP, TSM and TSDP reflect the consultation process undertaken by the project 
during  the  development  of  the  environmental  and  social  impact  assessment.  BP  Berau 
conducted additional consultations and disseminated information on the RIPP and the TSDP as 
well as on environmental safeguards in July 2016 to comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement requirements. 
 
39.  Other social dimensions. The project is classified as having some gender elements. 
Measures to benefit women or facilitate their involvement in the construction and operations of 
the project facilities have been incorporated in project design in accordance with ADB’s Policy 
on Gender and Development (1998). Such measures are embedded under the RIPP and the 
program. The project company will comply with national labor laws and, pursuant to ADB’s 
Social Protection Strategy, will take measures through its Tangguh’s workforce and industrial 
relations  management  strategy  to  comply  with  the  internationally  recognized  core  labor 
standards.22 The project company will report regularly to ADB on (i) its and its contractors’ 
compliance with such laws, and (ii) the measures taken. Information disclosure and consultation 
with affected people will be conducted in accordance with ADB requirements. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy  
40.  The  Tangguh  project  sponsors  and  operator  were  advised  of  ADB’s  policy  of 
implementing best international practice relating to combating corruption, money laundering, 
and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that the investment documentation includes 
appropriate provisions prohibiting corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism, 
and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
D.  Assurances 
41.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (the 
Charter), 23  ADB  will  proceed  with  the  proposed  assistance  upon  establishing  that  the 
Government of Indonesia has no objection to the proposed assistance to the project. ADB will 
                                                
22  ADB. 2003. Social Protection. Manila (adopted in 2001). 
23  ADB. 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila.

9 
enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following 
approval of the proposed assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
42.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$400,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to HSBC Bank USA, National Association 
for the Tangguh Liquefied Natural Gas Expansion Project in Indonesia, with such terms and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be 
reported to the Board. 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President 
4 November 2016

10   
DESIGN AND MONITORING FRAMEWORK 
Impacts the Project is Aligned With

increased economic activity (Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources, 2010) a 
 
Economic development for West Papua accelerated (Coordinating Ministry for Economic 
Affairs/Ministry of National Development Planning/National Development Planning Agency, 
2010)b
